abstract.para: The Federal Information Processing Standard (FIPS) Publication 140-2 is a U.S. government standard for validating the quality of cryptographic modules. An implementation of an approved cryptographic algorithm is FIPS 140-2-compliant only after it has passed National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) validation. This chapter provides guidance on whether admins should enable FIPS mode in &sle;, how to enable it, and links to resources with detailed information, such as certified modules, and relevant publications.

sect1.title: FIPS 140-2 timeline
sect1.para: The FIPS 140-2 standard was finalized in 2002, and is valid until September 22, 2026. On September 21, 2021, the Cryptographic Module Validation Program (CMVP) stopped accepting new modules for validation.
The FIPS 140-3 standard was accepted in March 2019, and will replace 140-2. CMVP has been accepting new module submissions for validation since September 2020 for FIPS 140-3.
See for a list of certified modules. (NIST, see ).

sect1.title: When to enable FIPS
sect1.para: FIPS does not provide system-wide protection TODO
The use case for enabling FIPS is simple: run your &slea; server in FIPS mode it when it is required to meet compliance rules. Otherwise, don't enable it.
When you are not required to meet compliance rules, running your servers in FIPS mode is most likely not a good idea. These are some of the reasons to not use FIPS mode:

listitem.para: FIPS is restrictive. It enforces the use of specific validated cryptographic algorithms, and specific certified binaries that implement these validated algorithms. You must use only the certified binaries.
Server and clients must use only approved binaries.
The approval process is very long, so certified binaries are always several releases behind.
Certified binaries, such as ssh, sshd, and sftp-server, run their own self-checks at startup, and run only when these checks succeed. This creates some small performance degradation.
Administering FIPS is complex and requires significant expertise.

sect1.title: Installing FIPS
sect1.para: It is best to install the patterns-server-enterprise-fips pattern on a new installation. Then, after the installation is complete, enable FIPS by running the steps in .

You may install patterns-server-enterprise-fips on a running system, but then it is likely you will have to make adjustments, such as regenerating keys, and audit the system to ensure it is compliant.

sect1.title: Enabling FIPS
sect1.para: Enabling FIPS takes a few steps. First, read the /usr/share/doc/packages/openssh-common/README.FIPS and /usr/share/doc/packages/openssh-common/README.SUSE files, from the openssh-common package. These contain important information about FIPS on &sle;.
Check if FIPS is already enabled:
crypto.fips_enabled = 0 indicates that it is not enabled. A return value of 1 means that it is enabled.

After enabling FIPS it is possible that your system will not boot. If this happens, reboot to bring up the GRUB menu. Press E to edit your boot entry, and delete the fips entry from the linux line. Press the F10 key to boot. This is a temporary change, and most likely the problem is an error in /etc/default/grub. Correct it, rebuild GRUB and initramfs, then reboot.
